SourcedStatement: To learn more about having a child tested or to schedule a free test, contact your child’s pediatrician, call the Shelby County Health Department at 901-222-9582 or email them at sch.clppp@shelbycountytn.gov.
Name: Shelby County Health Department
Justification: official health department providing resources for lead testing

SourcedStatement: To have your home tested, call the Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program at 901-222-7605 or the City of Memphis Lead-Safe program at 901-636-5323.
Name: Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program, City of Memphis Lead-Safe program
Justification: official programs providing resources for lead testing and hazard control

SourcedStatement: This story is brought to you by MLK50: Justice Through Journalism, a nonprofit newsroom focused on poverty, power and policy in Memphis.
Name: MLK50: Justice Through Journalism
Justification: nonprofit newsroom publishing the article, focusing on relevant social issues

Name: Jacob Steimer
Title: Housing and Development Reporter
Justification: author of the article, providing context and information on lead poisoning in Memphis

SourcedStatement: about 96% of residents are Black, and about 91% of homes were built prior to 1978, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.
Name: U.S. Census Bureau
Justification: authoritative source for demographic and housing data

SourcedStatement: Children in these neighborhoods primarily ingest lead from dust in their homes and yards.
Name: Children in these neighborhoods
Justification: residing in areas with high concentration of pre-1980 homes, as shown on the map

SourcedStatement: Kids raised in Memphis’ suburbs face little risk of lead poisoning since few homes there were built after 1978.
Name: Kids in Memphis suburbs
Justification: living in areas with low concentration of pre-1978 homes, due to suburban development patterns

SourcedStatement: Children in Cordova are far safer from lead poisoning than kids in Midtown. And children in Arlington are much better off than their counterparts in North Memphis.
Name: Children in Cordova, Midtown, Arlington, and North Memphis
Justification: residing in respective neighborhoods with varying concentrations of pre-1978 homes
